contentrichtext.text: {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{For|the Member of Parliament for [[Devizes (UK Parliament constituency)|Devizes]]|Percivall Pott (politician)}} [[File:Percivall Pott.jpg|thumb|right]] [[Knight|Sir]] '''Percivall Pott''' (6 January 1714 – 22 December 1788) born in London, England was an English [[surgery|surgeon]], one of the founders of [[orthopedy]], and the first scientist to demonstrate that a cancer may be caused by an environmental [[carcinogen]]. ==Life== He served his apprenticeship with Edward Nourse, assistant surgeon to [[St Bartholomew's Hospital]], and in 1736 was admitted to the [[Barbers' Company]] and licensed to practise. He became assistant surgeon to St Bartholomew's in 1744 and full surgeon from 1749 till 1787. As the first surgeon of his day in England, excelling even his pupil, [[John Hunter (surgeon)|John Hunter]], on the practical side, Pott introduced various important innovations in procedure, doing much to abolish the extensive use of [[eschar]]otics and the [[cautery]] that was prevalent when he began his career. He also thought that soot was a carcinogen. In 1756, Pott sustained a broken leg after a fall from his horse. It is often assumed that his injury was the same one that later came to be known as [[Pott's fracture]], but in reality Pott's broken leg was a much more serious compound fracture of the [[femur]]. As he lay in the mud and muck, he sent a servant to buy a door from a nearby construction site, then had himself placed on the door and taken home. Surgeons cleaned the wound and discussed amputation, an operation which at the time had a very high rate of failure (as it often led to sepsis and death), but Pott prevailed on them to splint the leg and he ultimately recovered completely.<ref>Gordon 1994, pp. 126–127</ref> In 1768, Pott published ''Some Few Remarks upon Fractures and Dislocations''. The book was translated into French and Italian and had a far-reaching influence in Britain and France. His name was written in the annals of medicine, by first describing arthritic [[tuberculosis]] of the [[vertebral column|spine]] ([[Pott's disease]]). He gave an excellent clinical description in his ''Remarks on that Kind of Palsy of the Lower Limbs''. Among his other writings the most noteworthy are ''A Treatise on Ruptures'' (1756), and ''Chirurgical Observations''. In 1775, Pott found an association between exposure to [[soot]] and a high incidence of [[Chimney Sweeps' carcinoma|scrotal cancer]] (later found to be [[squamous cell carcinoma]]) in [[chimney sweep]]s. This was the first [[occupational disease|occupational]] link to cancer, and Pott was the first person to demonstrate that a malignancy could be caused by an environmental [[carcinogen]]. Pott's early investigations contributed to the science of [[epidemiology]] and the [[Chimney Sweeper's Act of 1788]].<ref>Gordon 1994, p. 128</ref> In 1765 he was elected Master of the Company of Surgeons, the forerunner of the [[Royal College of Surgeons]]. ==See also== * [[Cancer cluster]] * [[History of medicine]] * [[Pott disease]] ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==References== *{{cite book | last = Gordon | first = Richard | title = The Alarming History of Medicine | publisher=St Martin's Press | location = New York | year = 1994 | isbn = 0-312-10411-1 }} * Dobson, J., 'Percivall Pott' in ''Annals of The Royal College of Surgeons of England'', vol. 50 (1972), pp. 54–65 ==External links== {{Wikisource1911Enc|Pott, Percivall}} * [http://www.surgeons.org.uk/history-of-surgeons/percival-pott.html History of Surgeons – Percivall Pott]. surgeons.org.uk England * [http://www.whonamedit.com/doctor.cfm/1103.html Article on Percivall Pott] in [[Who Named It]] * [http://www.surgical-tutor.org.uk/default-home.htm?surgeons/pott.htm~right Sir Percivall Pott].
